preventive: Plant resistant apple varieties like ‘Liberty’, ‘Enterprise’, or ‘GoldRush’
Prune trees in late winter or early spring to improve air circulation
Avoid overhead watering; water at the base early in the day
Clean up and destroy fallen leaves and fruit each season
Ensure adequate spacing between apple trees for airflow
Apply dormant copper spray before bud break
organic: Spray neem oil every 7-10 days during wet weather
Use horticultural sulfur sprays early, at first signs of infection
Use compost tea as a foliar application to boost plant immunity
Apply baking soda (sodium bicarbonate) solution with surfactant to reduce spore germination
Use beneficial microbial products if available
chemical: Apply Captan fungicide after petal fall according to label instructions
Use Mancozeb fungicide periodically in wet conditions
Use a protectant fungicide before ascospores are released
Alternate modes of action to prevent resistance
Apple___Apple_scab.notes: Apple scab spreads in cool, wet weather. Timing of sprays is critical.

preventive: Remove and destroy infected fruit and mummified apples
Prune out dead or diseased branches
Prevent injuries to fruit (insects, hail), which can allow infections
Maintain tree vigor with proper fertilization
Ensure good sunlight and airflow within canopy
organic: Apply neem oil spray covering fruit and leaves
Use compost tea to strengthen plant defenses
Copper-based organic fungicides applied early
Use dilution of sulfur or other allowed organic protectants
chemical: Use Captan or Thiophanate-methyl fungicides per extension recommendations
Apply fungicide after rainy periods when infection risk is high
Alternate classes of fungicides to reduce resistance risk
Apple___Black_rot.notes: Disease can overwinter in fruit and wood; sanitation is very helpful.

preventive: Avoid planting apple trees near juniper/cedar host plants
Prune galls from cedar in dormant season
Space trees for airflow
Remove cedar trees or remove galls nearby
Monitor new leaves for orange-yellow spots
organic: Spray neem oil at first sign of rust spot appearance
Sulfur sprays during early leaf development
Use horticultural oils to suppress spore germination
chemical: Use Myclobutanil or similar fungicide early when susceptible leaves are emerging
Apply protectant fungicides just before spore release
Repeat applications as needed in wet periods
Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.notes: Rust spores are airborne; preventative sprays are more effective than trying to cure once visible.

preventive: Monitor trees regularly for any signs of disease
Maintain soil fertility and water properly
Ensure balanced nutrition (avoid excess nitrogen)
Mulch to conserve moisture and reduce soil splash

preventive: Ensure correct soil pH (4.5-5.5) for blueberries
Mulch to retain moisture and suppress weeds
Provide good drainage and avoid waterlogging
Monitor for pests and diseases early
Blueberry___healthy.notes: Healthy blueberry. No treatment needed unless symptoms occur.

preventive: Prune to improve airflow and light penetration
Avoid shaded, crowded planting
Ensure proper spacing and prune interior branches
Water early in the day and avoid getting foliage wet in evening
organic: Apply sulfur sprays during bud break and repeated every 7-10 days under favorable conditions
Use neem oil sprays when mildew first appears
Apply biocontrol agents or microbial sprays if available
chemical: Use fungicides such as those containing myclobutanil according to label
Apply protectant sprays before disease is evident if conditions (humidity, shade) favor mildew
Alternate chemical classes to avoid resistance
Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.notes: Powdery mildew thrives in warm, humid, low light conditions. Early detection is helpful.

preventive: Regular monitoring for symptoms
Proper pruning and sanitation
Ensure good airflow
Balanced moisture and nutrient levels
Cherry_(including_sour)___healthy.notes: No treatment needed if no disease symptoms.

Use resistant or tolerant maize hybrids
Avoid heavy nitrogen fertilization
Manage residue from past crops properly

Time applications according to weather forecasts (humidity, dew)

Ensure wide spacing and good airflow
Avoid planting near fields with high rust pressure
organic: Neem oil sprays
Biological fungicides if available
chemical: Use fungicides with active ingredients effective vs rust (e.g. strobilurins)
Apply early when first pustules appear
Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.notes: Rust can spread rapidly; early detection helps.

preventive: Plant resistant varieties
Rotate crops and remove old residue
Avoid planting maize in the same soil too often
organic: Use neem oil foliar spray
Compost based sprays/supporting substances
chemical: Fungicides containing strobilurins or triazoles applied when weather is favorable
Multiple sprays during long periods of leaf wetness

Balanced fertilization
Timely irrigation without waterlogging

Use systemic fungicides when disease pressure is high

Avoid unnecessary wounding of vines
